Harvesting the Fruit of the Prickly Pear
The fruit of the prickly pear cactus, I:ibhai in O’odham, is one of the best traditional foods to collect from the summer through the beginning of October. While there are different varieties of I:ibhai, the most common are the hard fruits that are ripe during July and August.

Mrs. Murphy-Kennedy of SRES returns with another exercise in mindfulness. Today's lesson: Picturing peace.

Students are encouraged to draw a detailed picture of a place they find relaxing or peaceful. The challenge? Try to incorporate all five senses; what does the place look, sound, feel, smell, and taste like? Once your picture is complete and you have all the five senses in your mind, you can use this picture to look at whenever you feel stressed out. Concentrating on this place can help your mind and body relax, even for a moment.

Before #EarthDay50 ends we wanted to share this video of today’s fun at the Food Distribution site. All week we’ve been asking kids to think about how they could repurpose the milk cartons they get in their meals. Today they showed up with color holders, planters, tiny towns, various animals, and more! We hope to see more sustainable and creative innovations from these young leaders🌎

The Home Depot (located at the The Pavilions at Talking Stick) generously donated bird seed for those kids who made (or will make) bird feeders out of their milk cartons! 🐦🌵🌲

Also, we are so grateful to the SRPMIC Environmental Protection & Natural Resources team for donating amazing activity bags for the kids! If you want more ideas about how to celebrate Earth Day (EVERY day!), check out their website at https://www.srpmic-nsn.gov/government/epnr/earthday/#earthdayposter ♻️

Shout out 🙌🏽 as always to the fabulous Salt River Schools Food Services crew and the volunteers who make our weekday meal distributions possible. Mava sape🙏🏽🙏🏽🙏🏽

March Read Aloud Challenge: Lots of our FACE families signed up for the #21DayReadAloud Challenge (reading out loud for 15 minutes per day for 21 days), which takes place through the month of March! You can still participate - here's how:

1. Accept the challenge any time throughout March by posting a photo or video of you reading aloud with your child(ren) on Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram and continue reading aloud for at least 15 minutes for 21 days in a row. Make sure to tag Read Aloud or @ReadAloud_org for Twitter and @read_aloud_15 for Instagram with #21DayReadAloud.

2. Challenge 3+ people with a child under 8 years old to accept the challenge and pass it on.

3. Continue to post on social media. Use the tags listed above so we can share and celebrate your success while helping us spread the importance of reading aloud.

4. Keep track of your progress and get tips/materials at https://www.readaloud.org/challenge_resources.html

#Literacy #ReadfortheStars

The Canyon Athletic Association has put together a Multicultural Competency Committee to address issues related culture, inclusion, and sportsmanship within the CAA and its affiliated events. The committee is comprised of CAA members from various schools, including two from Salt River Schools. The committee created an ANONYMOUS survey to help us address these issues.

https://forms.gle/qaDFZJXgut3fLmje9

The purpose of the survey is to collect data from all CAA stakeholders (coaches, athletes, parents/fans, and school staff) on how we can better handle incidents concerning discrimination and/or disrespect during CAA-sanctioned events (i.e., regular season/postseason games or special tournaments) and school practices.

Please take your time with this ANONYMOUS survey. The information you provide will help us improve relationships and the overall environment and benefits of CAA sports.
